node.contents: I have this method which will generate a random maths expression solve it and output the answer to a variable:

astNode.text: I have this method which will generate a random maths expression solve it and output the answer to a variable:

elements.contents: public int Nov2() { char[] ops = new char[] {'+', '-', '*', '/'}; int i = rand.nextInt(4-0) + 0; char op1 = ops[i]; int novnum1 = rand.nextInt(101-1) + 1; int novnum2 = rand.nextInt(101-1) + 1; int nov2result = 0; switch(op1) { case '+': nov2result = novnum1 + novnum2; break; case '-': nov2result = novnum1 - novnum2; break; case '*': nov2result = novnum1 * novnum2; break; case '/': nov2result = novnum1 / novnum2; break; } String nov2Exp = novnum1 + " " + op1 + " " + novnum2 + " = "; Nov2resstor = nov2result; setContentView(R.layout.gameview); TextView display = (TextView) findViewById(R.id.exp); display.setText(nov2Exp); return nov2result; }

units.rawText: public int Nov2() { char[] ops = new char[] {'+', '-', '*', '/'}; int i = rand.nextInt(4-0) + 0; char op1 = ops[i]; int novnum1 = rand.nextInt(101-1) + 1; int novnum2 = rand.nextInt(101-1) + 1; int nov2result = 0; switch(op1) { case '+': nov2result = novnum1 + novnum2; break; case '-': nov2result = novnum1 - novnum2; break; case '*': nov2result = novnum1 * novnum2; break; case '/': nov2result = novnum1 / novnum2; break; } String nov2Exp = novnum1 + " "+ op1 + " "+ novnum2 + " = "; Nov2resstor = nov2result; setContentView(R.layout.gameview); TextView display = (TextView) findViewById(R.id.exp); display.setText(nov2Exp); return nov2result; }

elements.contents: public int Eas3() { char[] ops = new char[] {'+', '-', '*', '/'}; int i = rand.nextInt(4-0) + 0; char op1 = ops[i]; i = rand.nextInt(4-0) + 0; char op2 = ops[i]; int easnum1 = rand.nextInt(101-1) + 1; int easnum2 = rand.nextInt(101-1) + 1; int easnum3 = rand.nextInt(101-1) + 1; int eas3result = 0; if (op1 == '+' && op2 == '+') { eas3result = ((easnum1 + easnum2) + easnum3); } else if (op1 == '+' && op2 == '-') { eas3result = ((easnum1 + easnum2) - easnum3); } else if (op1 == '+' && op2 == '*') { eas3result = ((easnum1 + easnum2) * easnum3); } else if (op1 == '+' && op2 == '-') { eas3result = ((easnum1 + easnum2) - easnum3); } .../

}

node.contents: How about using recursion:

astNode.text: How about using recursion:

elements.contents: int num(int numberOfOperands, int current){ if(numberOfOperands<=0) return current; switch(rand.nextInt(4)){ case 0: return num(numberOfOperands-1, current + (rand.nextInt(100)+1)); break; case 1: return num(numberOfOperands-1, current - (rand.nextInt(100)+1)); break; case 2: return num(numberOfOperands-1, current * (rand.nextInt(100)+1)); break; case 3: return num(numberOfOperands-1, current / (rand.nextInt(100)+1)); break; } } int num(int numberOfOperands) throws Exception{ if(numberOfOperands <=0) throw new Exception("invalid number of operands: "+numberOfOperands); return num(numberOfOperands, rand.nextInt(100)+1); }

units.rawText: int num(int numberOfOperands, int current){ if(numberOfOperands<=0) return current; switch(rand.nextInt(4)){ case 0: return num(numberOfOperands-1, current + (rand.nextInt(100)+1)); break; case 1: return num(numberOfOperands-1, current - (rand.nextInt(100)+1)); break; case 2: return num(numberOfOperands-1, current * (rand.nextInt(100)+1)); break; case 3: return num(numberOfOperands-1, current / (rand.nextInt(100)+1)); break; } } int num(int numberOfOperands) throws Exception{ if(numberOfOperands <=0) throw new Exception("invalid number of operands: "+numberOfOperands); return num(numberOfOperands, rand.nextInt(100)+1); }

node.contents: If you're using Eclipse, as i presume you are...After you did the build thing, try writing some code and create a new instance of the class from JEval, as you know Eclipse underlines it with a red line and if you take your mouse over that, you can select the import line which you want and eclipse adds it automatically. OR, just create a new package in your src folder, only add the class files that were in the downloaded zip and then just import the package. Try it some more, you'll figure it out eventually :)

astNode.text: If you're using Eclipse, as i presume you are...After you did the build thing, try writing some code and create a new instance of the class from JEval, as you know Eclipse underlines it with a red line and if you take your mouse over that, you can select the import line which you want and eclipse adds it automatically. OR, just create a new package in your src folder, only add the class files that were in the downloaded zip and then just import the package. Try it some more, you'll figure it out eventually :)

node.contents: you can use the built-in Javascript engine.

astNode.text: you can use the built-in Javascript engine.

elements.contents: import javax.script.ScriptEngineManager; import javax.script.ScriptEngine; public class Test { public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception { ScriptEngineManager mgr = new ScriptEngineManager(); ScriptEngine engine = mgr.getEngineByName("JavaScript"); String foo = "40+2"; System.out.println(engine.eval(foo)); } }

units.rawText: import javax.script.ScriptEngineManager; import javax.script.ScriptEngine; public class Test { public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception { ScriptEngineManager mgr = new ScriptEngineManager(); ScriptEngine engine = mgr.getEngineByName("JavaScript"); String foo = "40+2"; System.out.println(engine.eval(foo)); } }

node.contents: What you're looking for is called the composite pattern. You define an abstract Expression base class and derive it.

astNode.text: What you're looking for is called the composite pattern. You define an abstract Expression base class and derive it.

node.contents: The classes must implement an evaluate() method which returns the result.

astNode.text: The classes must implement an evaluate() method which returns the result.

node.contents: One sub class will be the constant which return it's value, another one would be a binary expression like plus, minus, etc. The evaluate() method will add/subtract/etc the result of the evaluated sub-expressions.

astNode.text: One sub class will be the constant which return it's value, another one would be a binary expression like plus, minus, etc. The evaluate() method will add/subtract/etc the result of the evaluated sub-expressions.

node.contents: You can then build arbitrary expressions out of other expressions and then evaluate it without using one if condition.

astNode.text: You can then build arbitrary expressions out of other expressions and then evaluate it without using one if condition.

node.contents: If you've got n operations on n+1 numbers, and you do the first one, then you're left with n-1 operations on n numbers. You can use this as the basis for a loop that will process any number of items easily.

astNode.text: If you've got n operations on n+1 numbers, and you do the first one, then you're left with n-1 operations on n numbers. You can use this as the basis for a loop that will process any number of items easily.

elements.contents: int operate(int[] numbers, int[] operations) { if (numbers.length < 1 || numbers.length != operations.length + 1) { throw new IllegalArgumentException(); } int result = numbers[0]; for (int i = 0; i < operations.length; ++i) { result = operate(operations[i], result, numbers[i+1]); // where operate() is your switch statement } return result; }

comments.text: // where operate() is your switch statement } return result; }

node.contents: Yes, another way to do it is to write Command objects:

astNode.text: Yes, another way to do it is to write Command objects:

elements.contents: public interface Command<V> { V execute(Object ... args); }

units.rawText: public interface Command<V> { V execute(Object ... args); }

node.contents: You'll write an object that implements this interface:

astNode.text: You'll write an object that implements this interface:

elements.contents: public class AdditionCommand implements Command<Double> { public Double execute(Object ... args) { Double x = (Double)args[0]; Double y = (Double)args[1]; return x+y; } }

units.rawText: public class AdditionCommand implements Command<Double> { public Double execute(Object ... args) { Double x = (Double)args[0]; Double y = (Double)args[1]; return x+y; } }
